newsitem.title: THAILAND: Bank of Thailand says banks can cut lending rates.
newsitem.headline: Bank of Thailand says banks can cut lending rates.

text.p: Bank of Thailand governor Rerngchai Marakanond said on Monday that commercial banks can start cutting their prime lending rates as the central bank has restructured the way the minimum retail rate (MRR) is calculated.

He told a news conference that with the restructure of MRR, it would be unnecessary to cut the central bank's discount rate -- the rate the central bank charges on loans to commercial banks -- in order to bring prevailing high interest rates down.
After the restructure, the minimum retail rate will be calculated by up to a maximum of four percentage points above the minimum lending rate.
The rate will be charged at the discretion of commercial banks based on the credit worthiness of clients.
Previously, the minimum retail rate only reflected the cost of funds and not credit risk and was blamed for distorting the money market.
The minimum lending rate currently stands around 12.75-13.00 percent and is among the highest in the region.
